meta.title: Bears Will Be Boys
meta.description: A data analysis of animal gender in children’s books
meta.others: With Russell Samora, Michelle Pera-McGhee, Jan Diehm

content.value: If you spend any time with little kids, you’ll become (hyper)conscious of the way you narrate the world. “Look at Mr. Frog in the pond,” you’ll say. “Doesn’t he look grumpy?” And then you’ll catch yourself… Why did I say Mr. Frog? Why did I say he?
You’re conscious because you know that what you say shapes what they say, and how they think about the world. Little kids are kind of like large language models (LLMs) in this regard.

People hate that comparison (for good reason), but there’s some truth to it. You are part of their training data—just as your parents and mentors and everything else you’ve ever read, watched, and overheard have been for you. Your unconscious biases might become theirs.
But where do these gendered presumptions even come from, and how pervasive are they? Does everybody assume that a frog is a “he?” What about a cat, or a pig, or a bird, or a bear?
We wanted to know: Which animals do we gender, and why? And what does this tell us about our “training data”—about our baked in assumptions about gender, animals, and personhood?
Finding the Data
We started with arguably the richest source of anthropomorphized animals in human culture: children’s picture books.

We identified the most popular English-language kids’ books on Goodreads that feature at least one anthropomorphized animal.* We focused on the most rated titles since 1950, plus some older and still highly rated classics. We read about 30 per decade—nearly 300 books in total—and noted the gender of any anthropomorphized animal character who was important to the story.

details.value: Gender is one of the most complex aspects of human life—and perhaps animal life, too. Scholars have long distinguished between sex as a biological category (e.g., male, female) and gender as a social construction (e.g., man, woman, non-binary, etc.)—though both categories are now understood to be more fluid than once assumed. While gender has traditionally been viewed as a uniquely human concept, some scientists now believe that animals may have gender, too.

For the purposes of our study, we were interested in fictional animal characters, and the human conceptions of gender foisted upon them. Even so, determining the gender of animal characters is tricky.

For example, in Sandra Boynton’s But Not the Hippopotamus (1982), a bear and a hare appear in bow ties—a traditionally masculine accessory—but are never explicitly gendered in the text. Are they boys?

To avoid projecting our own assumptions based on clothing, visual cues, or names, we decided to go with a conservative approach. We only recorded how animal characters were referenced in the text: with feminine (she/her), masculine (he/him), or neutral (it, they/them) pronouns; with a gendered honorific (e.g., Mr., Ms.) or familial role (e.g., brother, mother); or simply by their animal name (e.g., the frog) or a character name.

While our later analysis focuses on how animals are represented along a gender binary, this reflects textual cues like pronouns. Gender, whether in humans or animals, is much more complex than this binary suggests.

content.value: We were also curious about people’s knee-jerk reactions to animals and gender. Authors make deliberate choices about the characters they create. More contemporary authors might be especially intentional about subverting gender stereotypes.
To dig into more automatic assumptions, we designed an experiment. We asked human survey respondents and an LLM (GPT-4o) to complete a story that began:
And then the bear said, “I must go to the river.” Upon arriving…

We randomly swapped in one of seven animals: bear, bird, cat, pig, duck, mouse, or dog. We didn’t tell participants—or the model—what the experiment was about, and even tried to throw them off the scent.*
More than 1,300 human respondents participated in our experiment. We ran GPT-4o 2,800 times, 400 times for each of the same seven animals, with 100 runs at each of four “temperatures*.”
Each continuation gave us a window into how the storyteller—either human or machine—imagined the animal, especially whether they assigned the animal a gender.
Which animals skew male vs. female?
So what did we find? Across all the children’s books, only a few animals were more consistently gendered female: birds, ducks, and cats.

content.value: That’s when we focus on characters who were explicitly gendered (she/her or he/him) and drill down to animals that appear in at least 10 different books.

content.value: The rest—frog, wolf, fox, elephant, dog, monkey, bear, rabbit, mouse, and pig—skew male, in descending order of dudeness. So automatically reaching for he after “look at the frog!” starts to make some sense. If children’s books are our training data, he is probably the next likely token.

summary.title: Act I
questions: What about gender neutral or ambiguous animals?
Enter: ChatGPT and the Vanishing Gender Problem

content.value: Mostly he, rarely she, and sometimes It

This bro-y trend holds for most animals. Male animal characters appeared twice as often as female characters across all the children’s books. They appeared nearly three times as often in the survey results (39% vs. 14%)—particularly striking because our respondents were mostly women—and eleven times as often in the AI-generated stories (11% vs. 1%).

She/her appeared in just 36 LLM-generated stories out of 2,400, and mostly in the outputs that were set to be more “random.” There were zero female animal characters at the most predictable temperature setting.
But what about animal characters who were presented as non-binary or not gendered at all?

In the children’s books, gender neutral language was rare. Only two percent of the animals were described as it. They/them was almost never used. About 19% of the characters were referred to simply by their animal name (e.g., “the frog”).

examples.alt: An illustration from The Rabbit Listened (2018) that shows two scenes. In the top half, a small brown rabbit approaches a scattered pile of yellow toy blocks. The text reads: "But it moved closer, and closer." In the bottom half, a child named Taylor with curly dark hair, wearing teal striped pajamas, sits curled up on the ground looking sad. The rabbit now sits quietly beside Taylor, leaning in. The text beside them reads: "Until Taylor could feel its warm body."
examples.caption: The rabbit from The Rabbit Listened (2018), written and illustrated by Cori Doerrfeld.

The kitten has bright yellow eyes and a neutral expression. The text reads: "The kitten just looked and looked. It did not say a thing."
examples.caption: A kitten from Are You My Mother? (1960), written and illustrated by P. D. Eastman.

examples.caption: A firefly from The Very Lonely Firefly (1995), written and illustrated by Eric Carle.

On the right, a large, shaggy musk ox named Cozy stands in the snow, sheltering several small animals beneath him. The text reads: "As winter went by, the storms grew worse. The wind blew and blew, and a low humpy shape appeared, swaying and shuffling. Its coat was covered with ice balls. 'Shaggy beast,' it growled, 'I fell into an ice floe and am chilled to the bone. Can you help me?' Cozy was happy to invite the wolverine in, but added to the house rules. 'Quiet voices, gentle thumping, claws to yourself, no biting, and no pouncing.'"
examples.caption: A wolverine from Cozy (2020), written and illustrated by Jan Brett.

content.value: There was a lot more gender neutrality and ambiguity in the human survey responses and LLM results—though, since their stories were much shorter than a typical kid’s book, it was perhaps easier to maintain gender neutrality. While he/him was still the most frequently used pronoun in the survey results, many respondents referred to the animal by name (26%) or by it (17%).
The LLM leaned into neutrality even more heavily. The model’s most commonly used referent—by far—was it, used in 72% of completions!

This result surprised us. We expected an LLM—trained on millions of human-authored documents, including surely thousands of kids’ books—to reflect, or even magnify, dominant cultural gender patterns. Instead, the model stood apart in the number of times it used no gendered pronouns.
Why would ChatGPT describe an anthropomorphized animal as it so often?

Our best guess is that OpenAI intentionally steers its models toward non-gendered pronouns in cases where gender is ambiguous, attempting to address the well-documented and deep-seated gender biases evidenced in AI models.

But our experiment shows that these well-meaning guardrails may have unintended consequences. By defaulting to it, the model doesn’t just neutralize gender; it virtually erases the possibility of a female protagonist altogether.

summary.title: Act II
questions: Why are there so few girl animals?

content.value: Where did all the girl animals go?
Why are animal gender ratios so lopsided in children’s books? And why are female animal characters even more absent in the stories produced by our survey respondents and the AI model?
Perhaps because the main character of a story is still assumed to be male by default—and maybe especially when the story’s setting lacks explicit social cues.

This aligns with decades of research—much of it quantitative—showing that male characters dominate children’s literature and media.[1] A 2011 study found that gender disparity was actually worse for animal protagonists. While representation of human girls and women improved over time, the animal world remained stubbornly male-dominated—at a ratio of about 2 to 1, similar to our findings.

value.Alt: Screenshot of abstract from classic 1987 study “The Three Bears Are All Boys: Mothers' Gender Labeling of Neutral Picture Book Characters” (1987) by Judy S. DeLoache, Deborah J. Cassidy, and C. Jan Carpenter. The text reads “Two studies examined mother's labeling of gender-neutral characters in young children's picture books. In the first study, mothers and their 18- to 38-month-old children looked at three popular children's books together. The mothers' use of masculine or feminine names or pronouns to refer to gender-neutral characters was recorded. The data revealed an extreme masculine bias: 95% of all characters of indeterminate gender were referred to by the mothers as males. In a second study, specially prepared picture books were used to examine the effect of gender-relevant variables on the mothers' labeling.”
value.caption: The classic 1987 study, “The Three Bears Are All Boys: Mothers' Gender Labeling of Neutral Picture Book Characters,” (1987) by Judy S. DeLoache, Deborah J. Cassidy, and C. Jan Carpenter.

content.value: Gender-neutral animal characters—those never explicitly gendered in the text—are often assumed to be male, too. In a classic 1987 study, mothers reading aloud to their children referred to ungendered animal characters as male 95% of the time. One of the only feminine designations was for a duck pictured with two ducklings—“Mrs. Duck.”
Though we didn’t keep track of the roles that characters played, we similarly observed that many female animals were moms, background characters for male leads.

content.value: There’s a kind of stealth sexism at work here. Because animal characters seem less connected to the human world, they seemingly sidestep pesky human problems. This idea has persisted in children’s publishing for decades.

Back in the 1970s, one book editor told researchers that animal characters just make things “easier”: “You don’t have to determine if it’s a girl or boy—right? That’s such a problem today.” Decades later, Marcia Wernick—the agent to children’s book author Mo Willems—echoed the same logic to a Washington Post reporter who had the same question we do. “Anthropomorphized characters have always been in the forefront of children’s books,” Wernick said, “because they enable the creator to not have to make decisions about is this a tall or short, black or white… character.”

value.Alt: The cover of “Don’t Let the Pigeon Drive the Bus!” written and illustrated by Mo Willems, featuring a gray illustrated pigeon who is never gendered.
value.caption: The ungendered pigeon from “Don’t Let the Pigeon Drive the Bus!” written and illustrated by Mo Willems.

content.value: But our findings suggest that when we turn to animals, that’s often when we most faithfully reproduce—and even exaggerate—the cultural norms we think we’ve left behind.

Feather Flores, an editor at Atheneum Books for Young Readers—an imprint of the “Big 5” publisher Simon & Schuster—told us that the idea of “universal” animal characters can be powerful but also problematic. “Anthropomorphized animals can be extremely useful as a vehicle for fable, allegory, satire, or social commentary,” she said.

value.alt: The cover of Watership Down (1972) by Richard Adams.
value.caption: Richard Adams’s Watership Down (1972), often cited as a powerful animal allegory.

content.value: But, Flores went on, “attempting to build relatability or universality by stripping away the ways we are embodied and experience the world as humans does not always (or, I would argue, usually) make for the most emotionally resonant stories.”
Beyond emotional resonance, is the absence of girl animals in children’s books really that serious? Does it actually impact how kids develop and see the world?

Yes, says Megan Fulcher, a professor of cognitive and behavior psychology at Washington & Lee University, who focuses on gender role development. “Differences in representation really matter no matter if characters are human or animals,” Fulcher said. This absence not only provides girls with few models, but it also prevents boys from practicing cognitive skills like empathy.

value.alt: Eight Marvel superhero action figures arranged in two rows. Top row, left to right: Captain America holding a shield, Iron Man in red and gold armor, Black Panther in a black suit with a gold necklace, and Spider-Man in red and blue costume. Bottom row, left to right: Ant-Man in a red and black suit, War Machine in black and silver armor with a shoulder cannon, Hulk with green skin and purple pants, and Falcon in a red and white suit with red wings.
value.caption: Action figures, conjuring an imaginative world void of girls.

content.value: Fulcher and her lab have found the same problem in kids’ toys. “Boy toys” like action figures and Legos often include few or no female characters, which makes “women and girls invisible in boys’ pretend play” and leaves their imaginative worlds “void of girls.”

If we apply this logic to picture books, the picture is rather bleak. Animal characters don’t just obscure girls and women; they obscure all kinds of human difference. A UK study found that there were more animal protagonists in British children’s books than Black, Asian, or ethnic minority protagonists. And, recently, animal characters have been used to represent transgender people, which writer Parrish Turner argues can fall flat or worse.
So much for sidestepping human problems. Animal characters don’t just reflect our biases. They often deepen them.

summary.title: Act III
questions: Why do we gender certain animals more than others?
Enter: The Patriarchy, Colonialism, & the TikTok “Black Cat Girlfriend”

content.value: Why are cats, birds, and ladybugs… ladies?

But if animal characters are assumed to be male by default, that still leaves a deeper question. Why do we gender certain animals in certain ways more than others—like cats and birds as females, or bears, wolves, dogs, and frogs as males?

content.value: It’s likely the result of a rich and long-simmering cultural soup: a mix of projected human stereotypes, symbolic associations, patriarchal structures, hard-coded linguistic habits, and famous media characters—with just a sprinkling of historical quirks to taste.

value.alt: The children’s book character Little Bear, an anthropomorphic bear, is stirring a big blue pot of soup.
value.caption: Little Bear tending to a long-simmering cultural soup. (Jk, Little Bear is making “birthday soup” in the 1990s television adaptation of Little Bear, originally written by Else Holmelund and illustrated by Maurice Sendak).

content.value: Large, strong animals like bears and wolves are often coded as masculine, while small, delicate animals like birds or kittens are more easily read as feminine.
(img)
There are also countless folk tales, stories, and cultural metaphors that connect certain animals with human gender, some of them dating back hundreds or thousands of years.

value.alt: The Egyptian funerary monument circa 800 BCE. One figure, center left, is a human woman with a cat head.
value.caption: The Egyptian goddess Bastet (center), depicted as a human woman with a cat head, in a funerary monument circa 800 BCE. Photo credit: Detroit Institute of Arts

content.value: While of course there are famous boy cats—think Garfield, Felix, Puss in Boots—cats have been linked to femininity and female bodies for a long time (the slang term “pussy” is literally hundreds of years old). Cats were linked to goddesses in ancient Egypt, to witches in medieval Europe, and more recently to figures like the lonely “cat lady” and the now TikTok famous “black cat girlfriend”—a term for a standoffish, introverted woman who is best paired with a “golden retriever” partner.

Birds, too, carry associations with femininity. You can think of the caged bird as a metaphor for constrained womanhood, all the women who get transformed into birds in Greek mythology, or the figure of a mother bird brooding over her eggs.

value.alt: The Egyptian funerary monument circa 800 BCE. One figure, center left, is a human woman with a cat head.
value.caption: This ancient Greek vase (circa 480-470 BCE) depicts a scene from The Odyssey, where the Sirens are represented as birds with women’s heads. Photo courtesy: British Museum

content.value: These associations are embedded in the slang we use everyday, even across languages like English and Spanish. As scholar Irene López Rodríguez reminds us, we call men “studs, bucks, wolves, toros (bulls), zorros (foxes) and linces (lynxes),” and we call women “chick, bird, kitten, pollita (chicken) or gatita (kitten).” López Rodríguez argues that these word choices aren’t arbitrary. Instead, they “shed some light onto the expectations and beliefs society holds about males and females.”
Thinking beyond English raises another important question: Does language influence how we perceive the gender of animals?

Some languages, like Spanish or French, have grammatical gender, where all nouns are gendered, even inanimate ones like “la mesa” (the table). In Spanish, many animals can be either masculine or feminine, such as the cat—el gato or la gata. But others, like the frog—la rana—are always grammatically feminine.
Are Spanish speakers more likely to perceive frogs as girls?
Maybe, at least according to a recent study. There are definitely Spanish children’s books with girl frogs in starring roles, like La Rana Mariana busca toda la semana or Rana de Tres Ojos.

value.alt: The cover of the children's book titled La rana Mariana busca toda la semana by Mar Benegas and Mariana Ruiz Johnson. content.value: But Spanish speakers also find creative ways to gender animals beyond grammatical gender. The famous Muppets character Kermit the Frog is masculinized through the addition of a traditionally male name—La Rana René in Mexico and Latin America, or La Rana Gustavo in Spain.*

The Spanish translation of Arnold Lobel’s famous Frog and Toad series uses a totally made up word, sepo—Sapo y Sepo, inseparables—to describe the iconic frog in slacks and distinguish him from his sapo (toad) bestie.

content.value: Still, it might not be a coincidence that both these examples are already famous male frogs imported from English.
Ladybugs are another intriguing case. Ladybugs appear in four different books in our dataset and are gendered female 75% of the time. Are ladybugs “ladies” in all languages?

content.value: Surprisingly, in many of them, yes. In the English language, the word ladybird—that’s what the Brits call ladybugs—and ladycow, another common term, originated around the 1600s. “Lady” was a reference to “Our Lady,” the Virgin Mary, apparently because both the beetle and the Holy Mother like to wear red. Ladybugs were also considered somewhat divine* because they devour the pests that plague farmers and gardeners (yes, they’re carnivores).

The name spread, likely through colonial networks and nursery rhymes (“Ladybird, ladybird/Fly away home”). In The History of the Ladybird: With Some Diversions of This and That (1989), A.W. Exell documents 329 names for ladybugs in 55 languages. A full quarter of them are linked to the Virgin Mary.

Social media users have been geeking out about worldwide ladybug names for years, too. In German, the ladybug is Marienkäfer (“Mary’s beetle”); in Spanish, Mariquita (“little Mary”); in Norwegian and Danish, Mariahøne and Mariehøne (“Mary’s hen”); in Friulian, a language spoken in Italy, Mariutine (“little Mary”); and in Icelandic, Maríubjalla (“Mary’s bell”).

Another widespread term is “God’s little cow”—also religious, feminine, and resembling the British “ladycow”—as found in Russian (bozhya korovka), Polish (boża krówka), and Hebrew (פרת משה רבנו). Many other names for the ladybug are similarly gendered, invoking young girls, little hens, and other diminutive feminine figures.

This reveals how the gendering of animals can be both arbitrary and deeply culturally ingrained. What began as, let’s face it, a kind of random symbolic association steadily became the ladybug’s gendered destiny in many parts of the human world. So while language definitely shapes how we view animals and the world around us, there are other powerful forces at work, too. Like those ever-present heavyweights: religion and empire.
Weirder, wilder, less predictable

So our gendered associations with certain animals—like the cat or the ladybug—are intimately tangled up with some of the biggest structural forces in our puny human lives: the patriarchy, colonialism, language, history. But also? We’ve learned that many of these associations are kind of… random. And that’s inspiring in its own weird way. While it may be a bummer to realize how much our mental maps are shaped by British imperialism and 17th-century religious iconography, it also means those maps can be redrawn.
Things aren’t going to change overnight. We found no clear progress toward equal gender representation in animal characters over the last 75+ years.

We talked to Megan Fulcher—a psychology professor at Washington & Lee University who studies gender role development—and asked if she was surprised about this. She wasn’t. Her lab recently found that gendered traits in toys have barely budged in the past 30 years. So it wasn’t a shock that books reflected the same stagnation.
Still, while broad patterns haven’t shifted, we did find plenty of meaningful exceptions.

content.value: While pigs were coded as male for a long time—hello, Three Little Pigs and the Big Bad Wolf—they took a strong feminine turn in the new millennium. In children’s books like If You Give a Pig a Pancake (1998), Olivia (2000), and the Elephant & Piggie series (2007-), pig characters are not only female but confident, curious, and central to their stories. So, pigs may be flipping the script.

Plus, there are thousands of children’s books that are not in our dataset. We focus here on ultra popular books, but a lot of parents intentionally seek out books beyond the mainstream. Outside the spotlight, in indie and lesser-known titles, animal characters are hopefully getting weirder, wilder, and less predictable.
That’s still one distinct advantage we have over large language models. We have the power to change our own training data.
How and why did we select these books?

We identified 30 popular children’s books with anthropomorphic animals for every decade since 1950, plus a catch-all category for everything before 1950. To do so, we first compiled a general dataset of English-language “picture books” that have been popular in the 21st century. We collected information about books that were tagged as a “picture book” the most times on Goodreads as well as those that were compiled into a list of well-known picture books by decade on Goodreads. We then supplemented this data with picture books that appeared on the New York Times bestseller list for children’s picture books—between June 2008 when the list started and August 2024 when we collected data—and picture books that were tagged as “animals” in the Children’s Book Database at Miami University.

To identify picture books that specifically feature animals, we then selected any book that had “animals” as one of its top Goodreads tags; any book that was tagged as “animals” in the Children’s Book Database; or any book that GPT-4o identified as featuring animals (after being prompted with its title, author, and description). We manually evaluated every book and every representation of animals, so we used this approach simply to reduce a large dataset to a manageable size. We exclude anthologies and collections, like Grimm’s Fairy Tales.
We ranked the remaining books by number of Goodreads ratings and selected the top 30 books from every decade.
What counts as anthropomorphic and “important to the story”?

We include animal characters that meet the following criteria: 1) the animal exists (or existed) in the real world; 2a) the animal is an active subject at some point in the book; 2b) the animal has dialogue or plays a role in the story; 3) the animal has at least one anthropomorphic quality (e.g., clothing, speech, upright walking, jobs, personality, uses tools, facial expressions, complex relationships, cultural behavior, lives in a house, etc.). We mostly focus on animals that are explicitly named in the story. We exclude animals that were only referred to as a group or in a plural form (e.g, “… said the birds”, “the squirrels jumped”).
How did we identify gender?

We identified the gender of animals based on how they were referenced in the text: with feminine (she/her), masculine (he/him), or neutral (it, they/them) pronouns; with a gendered honorific (e.g., Mr., Ms.) or familial role (e.g., brother, mother); or simply by their animal name (e.g., the frog) or a character name. Our analysis focuses on how animals are represented along a gender binary, but this reflects textual cues. Gender, whether in humans or animals, is much more complex than this binary suggests.
How did we handle different names for the same animal (e.g., bunny, rabbit)? What animals did we exclude?
Sometimes the same animal can have multiple names. For our analysis, we group together the following animal names: cat and kitten; dog and puppy; bunny, rabbit, and hare.

For our grid visualization, we group together some bugs (bug, maybug), some snakes (snake, python), sheep (sheep, lamb), fish (fish, trout, minnow, lantern fish), and birds (bird plus 19 specific bird types including stork, robin, sparrow, parrot, and others). We exclude gender-specific terms like cow, hen, rooster, and gander.
What is LLM “temperature”? What temperatures did we use?

Temperature is a parameter that controls the randomness of LLM outputs and is often considered a proxy for “creativity”—the higher the temperature, the more random the output. The default GPT-4o temperature is 1, and the possible range is 0-2. We used the following temperatures: 0, .5, 1, 1.5.

values: We included a catch-all category for everything before 1950, as well. Because we were interested in the books that kids are reading today, we defined “popularity” not by historical sales or readership but by contemporary relevance—specifically, the books with the most Goodreads ratings as of the past year.

Exell describes the ladybug as “the most venerated creature on earth over immense areas of space and stretches of time.” You could say he liked ladybugs.
